Decision of Character
Notwithstanding the importance of this trait of Character in all and especially youth it is seldom alluded to by those whose duty it is to instruct them. It should be lectured upon often by those who are able to handle the subject, that its importance may be seen and the evil avoided which result from a neglects of its proper cultivation. One of the greatest and most frequent faults of youth in general is Indecision of Character. They are too apt to pin their faith onto the sleeve of another. It is proper and even desirable that they should be ready and willing to receive instruction from whatever source it may be obtained, but it should not be received without reflection and if anything very important is presented it should be weighed and viewed in every possibly light in order that its imperfections as well as its beauties may be seen. For several reasons care should be taken not to form conclusions before the subject has been duly considered . Persons who have no principles of right, will sometimes clothe false and pernicious doctrines in habitments of grandeur in order to deceive weak minded persons that they may get their money and thus gratify their insatiable desire for riches. It will strengthen the intellectual powers to reflect and deduce conclusions which will be of great use in after life. The importance of having regular formed opinions on every general subject is very often felt in society. If they be formed carefully and arranged in such a manner that they may be expressed with ease and in language 
N11

that may be easily understood it adds much to the appearance of an individual. He does not feel as though his hands were in the way. And if a serious subject for conversation be introduced he does not wish it to turn upon something trivial but encourages a continuance of the same by taking an active part in conversing upon it. No one should desire or expect another to adopt his views till he has produced sufficient evidence to convince him of their truth. And no one should be content with teaching others who receive his instructions as exactly right but should encourage reflection on the part of the individuals whom he is laboring to enlighten. A preacher of the gospel that is well fitted for the station which he occupies will not be content with imparting instruction to those who take it for granted that everything he says is right but he will desire his hearers to take a deep interest in what is said and to examine for themselves and see that 'tis right and investigate the subjects that are treated upon each succeeding Sabbath still farther than he has to do in the short time that is allotted him. In this way anyone can form opinions of their own. He will be able to stand on his own footing, be independent of others in that respect. After opinions have been carefully formed in this way they should not be withheld for fear of ridicule but should be expressed whenever an opportunity is offered. The ridicule of anyone that will stoop to it when strong arguments are presented is not worth minding. His respect and esteem nee not be cared for much less desired but his company should be avoided for fear of being influenced by him to do as he has done.

There is great danger of falling into the other extreme which is adhering to opinions which have once been formed after sufficient evidence has been produced to convince any rational being of his error. It is very unpleasant to converse with a person of this character, for having once formed his opinions in regard to any subject he will never yield them for fear that he will not appear dignified if he acknowledges himself mistaken. It ought to be the desire of every one to learn the truth and this is a great obstacle in arriving at it. Such persons will progress very slowly in whatever undertaking they engage and will gain the ill rather than the good will of the public and their associates will not respect them as they otherwise would. signature cut off?

(For the casket) Though poverty may confine the physical comforts of man to quite a small number yet it can never effect the mind otherwise than by giving it greater energy. It is one of the surest means of calling out all the faculties of the mind. Among whom do we find the most brilliant imaginations? It is among those who are deprived of the means of obtaining luxuries for those who revel amid scenes where no energy is required, where nothing is to be done but to indulge in the gratification of all those desires which have a tendency to degenerate men are rendered stupid and unfit for the more refined employment of exercising the imagination. When seated as am I want to be under a thatched roof with no room made comfortable by a warm fire which I can call my own and with no furniture but such as is absolutely necessary and no wardrobe of silk and satin but one consisting only of such things as are most economical whether they exactly suit the fancy of their owner or not. It is then that the imagination takes its flights. Ah! It is people who are deprived of comforts and who have to exert themselves for all that they obtain that know how to appreciate the blessings which are bestowed on them. Labor sweetens everything, makes every faculty energic and renders the physical, mental and spiritual being of man more susceptible of impressions calculated to enhance his happiness. While our land is one of freedom we need not lament that wealth is not ours, but we ought to be thankful that happiness may be by employing

the means which are at our hand. In this abode where naught that is luxurious or magnificent has a place, in imagination I roam over the vineclad hills of a distant forest, beholding at every step some new object of beauty and interest which leads me to exclaim, "There is beauty and sublimity in all the works of God," or I visit the natural curiosities of the world sometimes Niagara Falls and gaze with untold delight on the stupendous works before me. It is not one or two days that I may thus gaze, but weeks and even months and daily does the scene change for the better, and I am led to exclaim with greater emphasis, "There is beauty and sublimity in all the works of God!" Sometimes I am transported in imagination to the Mammoth Cave and there wander over every part, examine each and endeavor to form conceptions of the skill and wisdom of the Great Architect. Palaces of splendor I approach with as much pleasure as though I was in possession of them and enter then seat myself with as much complacency as though I was in the habit of really living in such. A seat beside the windows is very attractive let us sit there a few moments this glorious moonlight night. A servent enters and inquires if she shall bring lights or if we will go to the adjoining parlor. The moonlight is preferable and let us enjoy it, though all within is of the finest style, damask curtains, marble tables, brussels carpet, silk coverd lounges, pier glasses reaching from the ceiling to the floor, etc., we will not notice or describe them but the scene without which nature furnishes

somewhat modified by the works of art claims our attention. The cool and damp weather which always comes at the opening of Spring is over and we may raise the window that our view of the surrounding scenery may be enlarged. The window raises and immediately the room is filled with the most delicious perfumes, the beholder is stupified for a moment with the shock produced by the grandeur of the scene. Through the vines trellised over the window may be seen the bright and beautiful queen of night with her myriads of stars casting there silent though comprehensive beams upon the earth to gladden the hearts of men and to display complete the beauty of the scene. As those bright orbs mirror themselves in the wide expanse of water that spreads itself at the foot of the gently sloping yard, covered with the most beautiful flowers, plants and shrubs, how can their beauty be compared with works of another kind? Words are inadequate to paint the beauty of such a scene but a sense of any own insignificance strikes me not on account of my poverty in regard to property but my poverty of soul. A lover of truth.

How dear are all - 
together
How dear are all the ties that bind out race in gentleness 
Man is not an isolated being; but is intimately connected with his fellow man. The materials of which the connecting chain consists very according to the circumstances. At a very early age the links begin to form and continue to increase in number and strength till they become a complete and indissoluble chain. Though this chain unites us together yet it is wound so gently about our hearts that it does not lessen our happiness but rather tends to deepen and refine it. It is never considered burdensome but the stronger and more enduring it is the happier the heart around which it is bound. The first link in the chain is, affection for the kindred. The infant is bound to its mother by this which ripen and strengthen with each succeeding year of its life or as the poet has it. 

     "The heart is formed as earth was its first age Formless and void and fit but for itself Then feeling half alive just organized Come next."

And as his young life puts for its powers new, dear and lasting ties spring into being within him. The becomes attached to those with whom he associates for by witnessing the same scenes and engaging in the same sports and avocations a mutual interest is engendered and by conversation they learn that a general congeniality of thought and feeling has grown
N9

up between them. How often do we notice the conversation of persons who have not met for many year turn upon something that happened at the time of their acquaintance though it might have commenced on a subject the most remote from it. This is in consequence of the deep impressions made on the mind at the time and the principle of the association. The presence of this old acquaintance bring to mind all the former scenes in which they both participated, and the memory of these past scenes being pleasant each individual is kindly looked upon as a contribution to the happiness of the other and in this way an attachment is formed which is very endearing. We often notice the effects which are produced by the principle of associated in foreigners. When foreigners that never met before meet in this country, they feel that they are meeting in the presence of old friends who can appreciate their worth and in whom they can confide; in fact those who can understand their feelings. This can be very easily accounted for by considering that as a nation they are bound together by lasting ties, and that they have the same interests, hence the congeniality of feeling that exists. 
It is true that the love for the human race exists in different degrees in different individuals, but it is supposed that all are naturally philanthropic, notwithstanding habits and dispositions may be formed that will cause enmity to exist towards all mankind. The greatest number of institutions for the unfortunate prove that they are the objects of a general sympathy. It is this philanthropic feeling for them that prompts individuals to aid in the establishment of these

benevolent institutions, and it was this that led the founders to devise the best means by which this could be accomplished. When it is known that any of the human race are in a suffering condition an interest is immediately felt in them and in consequence of this interest all the means within reach are used to alleviate their sufferings. As in illustration of what I mean, - the news reached this country that the people of Ireland were in danger of starvation from the failure of the principle article of food among the poorer classes. The good feelings of the people of this country were immediately around and they raised large quantities of provisions and sent to their relief. From the great number of instances of this kind that are presented to our view we have sufficient proof that the whole human race are bound together by ties which are very dear and lasting. J.C. Stedman

Ladies and Gentlemen
Ladies and Gentlemen, Ocean, Air, Earth, Stars are filled with our Father's writings.  We have met together this evening to hear something of the texts contained in the Book written by God's own hand & spread out before us as upon the bosom of the Universe.  Before we can comprehend what man has written we must understand the characters they use & also the relations those characters have to each other  when classified & arranged.  Even so we must understand the alphabet which God has used in his writings before we can understand what he has written in Nature.  A Book although filled with the most glorious truths is as meaningless as a piece of blank paper to a person who cannot read.  Even so he who has never learned to interpret the characters God has inscribed upon all material things to tell us of himself knows comparatively nothing of those glorious writings constantly before him.  Our Father has given us two Revelations the scientific or the Revelations contained in the Bible, & both of these Books can be understood without effort & patient industry, but, each is replete with gems of knowledge & likely repays the student for all his labor in a coin that neither mold nor rust can corrupt.  Knowing as we do that all things around us are covered with the hand writing of the eternal how strange it is that we spend so little time in investigating his messages to us!  Geometry is but the name for those principles in accordance with which Jehovah formed the Universe balanced the planets in their orbits & jammed nights curtains with glittering Worlds. When we study the science of astronomy we are investigating those great truths concerning our Father which he has written in the heavens with the stars.  Geology teaches us the manner in which God formed this Earth our

present home, this beautiful Earth, It takes us back to Earths infancy, we can trace its progress down through the dim distant past step by step from a chaotic mass to the time when God spoke into existence the present order of animals, & formed "Man in his own Image" & we can almost hear the strains of that celestial Music which came pealing from the vaulted heavens when the "Morning Stars first sang together." Physiology speaks to us in a language that cannot be misunderstood, of God's goodness to, & love for man, by showing us how perfectly adapted our physical nature is to the material world in which we live, or by pointing out many wonderful contrivances by which the body is made the communication of pleasurable emotions to the mind.

The March of Life
How smoothly and happily do some persons move through life, while others are continually stumbling and hobbling along as though they thought the road almost impassable or at least very rough. To what is this attributable? Is the fault ours or is some one else to blame? When we stop to consider for a moment we answer that it rests with ourselves whether our march be one of ease and happiness or one of pain and misery. The March of Life may be compared to a long journey through pleasant valleys and over steep hills, through dreary wastes and peopled cities. In order that a journey of this kind may be pleasant and agreeable the traveler must be equipped for it, must be prepared to brave all the dangers to which he may be exposed. As he is aware that storms may come he takes along necessary articles to prevent the rain from injuring him, and he knows that his team must be strong else it will break down while crossing some of the large hills. He must also have some wealth in order to pay his expenses and must be careful of what he says lest it may injure someones feelings and thus he would loose the respect which eh thinks is due him. When he enters a crowded city in

which people meet and pass each other he must be accommodating enough to pass out of a direct line or he will come in collision with someone or something and then he would have to stop but by yielding a little this would not happen. It will also make his journey much pleasanter if he lets his mind rest upon the beauty of his journey and when in difficult places he looks forward to what is coming thinking it will be more pleasant. When his journey is accomplished and he looks back over his dangers and pleasures he attributes his good success to being well prepared for what might happen and to his accommodating spirit. It is the same in marching through life. Those who prepare themselves for all the dangers to which they may be exposed get along easily while those who are subject to injury in every storm that may rise find that they are passing unhappily along. Those who are accommodating have no trouble for they find that other people use them as they use others and that there is more happiness in being contented than in any other way. It only requires patience and humility to march through life without being rendered unhappy by the hardships and vexations which every one has to endure in a greater or less degree. 
J.C. Stedman

The morning --
The morning of the 4th of July broke upon the inhabitants of a city situated on the shores of a clear and beautiful lake in great splendor. What more beautiful or sublime spectacle than a sunrise upon the water, it was more than usually grand and sublime at this time as a number of clouds were to be seen lying in the horizon, displaying all the varied colors of the rainbow. Flashes of light were seen streaming through the air, sent as warnings of the approach of the Wing of day and as they increased in number and brilliancy the sunbeams still more imposing. It is useless to attempt a description of what the soul can scarce comprehend. Let us turn from it but our eyes fall upon some objects at a distance which as they approach are discovered to be ships. As they glide along so smoothly and slowly a spectator cannot but be struck with their grace and simplicity, contrasting well with the grandeur and magnificence of the scene presented by nature, and is led to inquire "What is man that Thou art mindful of him?" But few there were to witness this sublime spectacle as most of the people were yet wrapt in the arms of ?Morpheus unconscious of the magnificence with which they were surrounded. Among the chosen few who witnessed this scene was a maiden whose countenance I shall ever remember as it lighted up at each change in the scene revealing the feelings of the heart. 
N20

Let us return to the city, get some refreshments and be ready to gaze at the comical sights that will no doubt meet our vision today as this day is to be celebrated as usual and all the people from the raggedest boy in the street to the greatest nabob will make this appearance in order to spend 4th of July somewhere besides at home. Breakfast is dispatched in due form and we will take a seat by the window, the sun has already  performed a large share of his days work and the people begin to pass. Some boys are seen passing with pop guns, wooden swords, paper caps etc. Some numbers of the military company are next in order followed by men women and children of all shades and hues going in the same direction, but here is one going in the opposite direction, ah! I have not forgotten that form or countenance, it is the same lady that we saw during our morning walk. How happy she looks! Let us follow her to her home. She is carrying a bundle, perhaps she has been making purchases. She enters her home that is no palace or place of luxury but a quiet pretty cottage and is greeted by a brother and a sister, apparently much younger than herself, the only remaining members of the household. Joyful the greeting, though they have been separated but a short time but joyful because the sister brings welcome news. She tells them of her success in obtaining means by which to aid them in their endeavors to obtain an education. What news could be more welcome to their hearts! The brother and sister resume their studying and painting

and the elder sister is left alone; she draws from her bosom a miniature, the miniature of her dead mother, imprints thereon a kiss, then gazes at it long and repeats her vows again and again to watch over and protect those left to her charge, instill into their minds those holy precepts which had been taught her from the bible. She gazes long - in the meantime contemplating the past history of her life and forming conjectures for the future. She is, thus seated in contemplation a fit subject for a painter or poet; none other couple delineate half the beauties of that being, engaged in such a delightful occupation, what serenity in those books! They speak volumes! They tell of the beauty of submission to the Divine will and say that the heart never wearies but still looks forward to a bright and glorious time even though the physical powers are the tasked with more than they can bear, that though storms may gather around, though sorrows and pains may bear upon the mind, yet that the bright rays of hope are still able to shine forth and prevent clouds from gathering on the brow, that sorrow teaches wisdom, renders the soul more pure and tells it to speed on in its endeavors to attain that degree of perfection which shall make it worthy of a position among the brightest and most glorious things of earth.

Musings
After a warm and sultry day, spent in endeavoring to learn lessons, but which I found impossible on account of the weather I wandered forth to enjoy the cool and quiet of the evening I soon released from my mind the less pleasant transactions of the day and was wholly absorbed in thought, finding it less difficult to learn lessons from nature than from books. It was a beautiful evening. The balmy breeze of the evening contrasted well with the close air of the day. I prolonged by walk till I reached the shore of a beautiful stream where I was impelled by the beauties by which I found myself surrounded to stop. While gazing around, first upon the clear water which reflected the moon and glittering stars, disturbed here and there by fishes coming up to get a little more air. Then at the silvery moon, which shone with more than ordinary splendor surrounded by thousands of stars, and listening to the evening song of the whipperwill which could be distinctly heard, I thought that surely that scene could be interpreted as easily as thought it were written in language. It spoke volumes and it was very pleasant to the ears of one who was thirsting for knowledge, who was desirous of learning whether regarding science, morality or religion. 
It has been said that "Grace, beauty, and sunshine are preeminent satellites in the moral world" it was recalled to my mind on beholding this scene. The moon is shining in all her brilliancy was indeed a beautiful object to behold and though the stars were not as bright as they would have been in the absence of the moon yet I beheld them with as much interest for I thought a lesson might be

learned from them. They seemed to acknowledge the superiority of the moon and appeared to retire from her too immediate presence in order that they might not shock her with their boldness in presuming to come out in all their dazzling brightness while she appeared so simple and unassuming in her bright though not dazzling splendor. They seem to know that they are not so much needed in her presence. Am important lesson may be learned from them it is to be modest, never to be guilty of acting rudely or in an ostentatious manner, to retire from the presence of the gifted and noble or at least not to crowd ourselves or rather our opinions which from our limited knowledge are not worthy of as much notice upon them, to always allow those most capable of judging to express themselves first. How much more graceful beautiful and with how much more admiration does that beholder witness an act however praiseworthy if performed in a simple manner than if paraded before the world; those who are cautious in this respect will meet with fewer sneers than those who take a different course. How much higher in the estimation of the refined and sensitive do those stand who appear modest on all occasions while the rude can continually shocking them with their rough manners.
It is not necessary that anyone should sit as quiet as a lamb continually but they may with [unclear] let all their lively feelings play freely if they will but let them be well timed, and modesty may be considered as a predominant characteristic in them. If well timed laughter, joking, and merriment are not only allowable but are desirable employments, but to force it upon people when it is not called for is rude in the extreme.

Before returning I looked around once more and "God is Love" seemed
to ring in my ears. It was breathed forth by every living thing around, 
it floated on the breeze. It is asserted in the Scripture and all
nature seemed to repeat the strain. It is a glorious truth, sublime
thought and how happy are we when contemplating that "God is Love."
If speaks to our hearts and our tenderest feelings and it is the 
source of much pleasure to those afflicted, it cheers the lonely,
rouses the inactive, gives the most desolate a hope. Whatever afflictions
fall to the lot of man if he be duly impressed with the belief
that it is through love they are upon him they become lightened
and we are assured that "he does not afflict willingly or grieve the 
children of men but though he cause grief yet will he have compassion
according to the multitude of his mercies." Time admonished me 
that I must retrace my steps though I regretted leaving
a place so beautiful to me and from which I thought I had 
learned much.
J. C. Stedman

Passing Away

      It requires but a moments reflection to see that all things of earth are gradually decaying and passing away; but their places are supplied with more which flourish for a time and meet the same fate as their predecessors.  So has it been from time immemorial and will no doubt be for ages yet to come.  All animate creation can according to the laws of nature exist but a few short years at most.
     Flowers bloom in all their beauty and loveliness for a time, long enough to accomplish their work and then fade and finally drop from their stems and pass into different forms to bloom again when their season returns.  More hardened plants and trees retain their beauty longer but time which ne'er forgets to set its withering blast upon all created things comes and makes them feeble and unable to withstand the raging tempests longer, and so they fall to the ground and there decay or pass into different forms which are very useful in furnishing food and nourishment to surrounding objects.
     We see that it is the same with man.  When we reflect upon the past scenes of our lives we observe that many individuals who participated in our pleasures and who sympathized with us in our bereavements have already passed away while others have not yet gone but their beauty has departed and they are only waiting for the time when their souls shall take their flights to realms on high where the strong hopes which they entertain here of meeting their loved friends

shall be realized and where we are assured there will be no more troubles, cares or trials to disturb their peace and happiness and so of course nothing to make them fade or become less attractive.  It would be very unpleasant to think of the departure of our friends and also to contemplate our own were it not for the fact that a hope which amounts almost to a certainty exists in every breast that there will be a hereafter.  It has been said "What is excellent
As God lives, is permanent:
Hearts are dust, hearts' loves remain;
Hearts' loves will meet again."
Tis not a alone of material things we may say passing away but also of time.  The moments are fast receding from us, sometimes we note them not but when we consider that it is these that make up our lives then can we see how imperfect it is to improve them, to let no opportunity from which any good may result pass but always be on the watch.  It may appear to some as though there was no use of their learning certain things for they think or say they will never have any use for such knowledge.  This is a mistake.  No one knows what he may have an opportunity to do for there are great changes continually taking place; reversals of fortune are frequent.  Thus we see that all things are transitory and if we wish to make the most of everything we must be on the watch.

Power of Habit
The mental as well as moral constitution of man is under the influence of habits which are acquired by repetition or practice. By constant practice we form habits of walking, talking and writing that characterize us at all times, by which characteristics our acquaintances are able to recognize us. The facility with which some learn to repeat passages and the ease with which some appear on the stage both declaiming and reading compositions is to be attributed to habit. Though genius and a moderate share of self esteem is requisite to a good speaker and writer, they are wasted unless we habituate ourselves to speaking and reading before the public. For instance let two individuals equally talented, one in the habit of appearing before the public and the other not, be called upon to deliver a lecture; one would appear graceful and easy in his manners while the other would appear awkward and therefor uninteresting. The sense of touch, taste, smell, hearing and sight can be cultivated by practice so as to serve various purposes for which without cultivation they are wholly unfit. By the loss of one of the senses the others are called into use and are thereby brought to a greater state of perfection. Those who are deprived of the sense of sight cultivate the touch till it becomes so nice that they may without fear traverse grounds that they have been over and go through the house and find anything they may wish being able to distinguish their own things from others though they appear just alike
N8

The blind can by feeling read in which case they substitute the fingers for the eyes. The sense of smell will also become nicer as it is brought into use. The presence of bodies which have no perceptible odor to persons in general are detected in this way by the blind. The sense of sight may also be improved by habit as may be noticed in the sailor and engineer and by cultivating this sense the deaf can tell what their friends are saying to them by the onion of their lips and the gestures they make. In this point of view the law of habit may be considered as of great benefit to the human race. But there is another view which may be taken of this law which leads to different and sometimes unpleasant results. The taste becomes more delicate by use. It will enable persons to distinguish the flavors of different dishes when there is but a very nice distinction. The taste becomes vitiated by habitual use of anything that is stimulating as may be seen in the users of tobacco, snuff or ardent spirits. Anyone who meddle with any of these will become their slaves and devote the rest of his life, whether it be one or fifty years to their service.  The only way to get entirely rid of these bad habits is to pledge yourselves never again to touch those things which have caused them. 
J.C.S.

When travelling a few miles out from the city of Cincinnati, it was my good fortune to put up for the night at a house where there was to be a wedding. A beautiful daughter of the landlords was to be married that evening and I was invited in to see the ceremony performed. A great number of people of all ages and sizes assembled to witness the joyful scene. Some appeared sedate and thoughtful other giddy and thoughtless while the bride was about half way between. I could not help noticing her as she moved around among her acquaintances how graceful was every motion and how expressive every look. After the crowd had dispersed and the weddingers had reached the boat that was to transport them to a distant land I retired to my room and wished to myself perhaps out loud that I knew the history of the young lady when to my surprise the hearthstone broke forth in the following strain. Tis just twenty years since first I knew Eliza. She was then a most beautiful creature the pet of the family. As is usual with girls she was humored and petted till she thought she must always have her own way and she always had till she was twelve years old when her mother died and she was placed in the care of an aunt who was more as a parent should be than was her natural parent. It was well for Eliza that she had a more suitable instructress and companion though it was hard to submit such strict and as she thought needless government. She had acquired many bad habits which it was hard to break. She would often come in crying and complaining of her aunt

"The Pleasant Task"
The pleasant task of tracing the history of the Grecians and Persians during the reigns of Darius I and Xerxes I is assigned to me. For want of a knowledge of their history save such as I have gained from the perusal of a few books I am obliged to offer you nothing better than the following which is an attempt to condense the history of the Grecians and the Persians from 521 B. C till 478 B. C, the space of forty eight years. Darius was known by the name of Ochus before his reign but his name was changed to Darius signifying an avenger on account of the manner in which he treated the Magian impostor whom he finally succeeded in destroying. He reigned thirty years. Darius is mentioned in history as having several wives one before his ascension to the throne by whom he had a son; Artobarzanes who afterwards disputed the throne with Xerxes. It must be borne in mind that Darius did not come in possession of the throne by heirship or in consequence of his virtues but it was agreed upon by the conspirators against the Magian Impostor that he whose horse neighed first on a certain day should be king; Darius groom procured the honor for his master by means which he took for that purpose. The king, feeling grateful for the favor erected an equestrian stature upon which was inscribed, "Darius the son of Hystaspes acquired the king of Persia by means of his horse (whose name was inscribed and that of his groom." The Persian Empire was very extensive at this time including several countries belonging to Europe Asia and Africa. When Darius was seated on the throne his first action was in reference to dividing the Empire into districts which he designed according to their wealth at the same time using great care to appear to do all in his power for the good of his subjects and also not to displease them by taxing them too heavily, but the Persians did not like his proceedings and gave him a name which signifies something more mean and contemptible than merchant while Cyrus and Cambyses were surnamed by

the same people father and master. By means of these taxes 2,000,000 per annum were drawn from the people. An idea of Davis' want of humanity may be obtained from the following not every flattering account of him. On one occasion he received an injury by falling from a horse and employing Egyptian physicians who did not succeed in restoring him to health as early as he wished condemned them to death. Kings may be good men but it is seldom they are faultless, they forget to "honor all men" but contrary to the teachings of Christianity claim that all honor is due one man. Democedes, a Grecian physician of Crotona effected the cure of Darius and through his influence the Egyptian physicians were pardoned for the great crime of not being able to cure the king. Democedes rec'd many magnificent presents for his services on this occasion and having the good fortune to perform a cure for Stossa the favorite wife of the king he was allowed to revisit his own country once more which he had been obliged to have the apparently unimportant affairs of which I have just read came near producing rather serious results. Stossa proposed to Darius to send persons with Democedes into Greece in order to make necessary examinations of the country for carrying on a war with them telling him that by engaging them in this war he would win for himself honors and show his people that their leader was a man of courage besides said Stossa "I have heard great things in favor of the women of Lacedaimon, Argos, Athens and Corinth and should be glad to have some of them in my service. Fifteen Persian noblemen were sent with Democedes who were instructed to bring back the physician but being taken up and imprisoned Democedes fled to Crotona. When liberated they returned home to find the king engaged in other affairs though Darius did may things for which he deserves censure yet the encouragement and assistance which he gave the Jews in the erection of the temple at Jerusalem and also his treatment of them shows that he was not devoid of feeling and especially

does he appear in a more agreeable light when we view him acknowledging as his benefactor a man who had when young presented him with a suit of clothes which pleased Darius at the time very much. This is an evidence to me that he was not as proud and arrogant as he might be, "In the beginning of the fifth year of the reign of Darius, Babylon revolted and could not be reduced till after a siege of twenty months". The Bablonians occupied four years in preparing for this war but Darius with the whole force of the Persian Empire succeeded in destroying the city which had been threatened in a terrible manner even though the Babylonians used every means to preserve it in their power adopting such outrageous resolutions as the following, that of destroying all such persons as were not servicable even their wives and children by strangulation. The bablonians strengthd so much their forces in this manner that they regarded them as impregnable and for a time they did seem to render the unwearied efforts of the Persian fruitless but fortune favored them after the lapse of eighteen months. Zophyrus, a devoted friend of the kings feeling a strong desire that Darius should succeed in the enterprise in which he had been obliged to engage, caused his own ears and nose to be taken off and himself to be covered with many wounds then presented himself to the king stating his intention of going in this conclusion to the enemy and representing there that he had been thus injured by the king for daring to advise him to give up fighting against a people as well armed as they had had proof that the bablonians were. He went and as he anticipated was placed commander over many troops finally he was intrusted with guarding the gates of the city which he allowed Darius to enter without any resistance. As a reward,  Zophyrus was given the whole revenue of this great city but nothing could restore him to his former beauty nothing fully compensated him for his daring deed. Darius caused the walls of the city to be taken down and pardoned all the inhabitants save 3,000 of the principal actors in the revolt. After Darius' capture of Babylon he commenced war with the Scythians, a nation

of which we have many contradictory accounts. All historians however agree in representing them as extremely ignorant and savage, not avaricious and even destitute of a knowledge of the use of gold and silver but ever anxious for virtue. As was a Scythian king who taught his sons the following beautiful lesson. The king on his death bed called all of his sons to him and gave to each one after another a bunch of arrows desiring them to break them. "Then he untyed the arrows and giving them one by one they were easily broken. Let this emblem said the father be a lesson to you teaching you the great advantage which results from unity & concord". As the Scythians became intermingled with more learned and avaricious nations they seemed to lose their peculiar characteristics of innocence simplicity and frugality and were transformed into very different individuals. It was before this change that Darius warred with them. There seems to have been no real cause for this war but was engaged in on the part of Darius to gratify ambitious desires. He did not as his brothers advised him consider whether it was just and for the good of his subjects but hastily assembled a large army with which he thought to conquer them easily and marched forward but he soon wearied of the long marches which he was obliged to take through countries which the Scythians had rendered destitute of water by filling up the wells and springs which were not very abundant at any time. Darius desiring to put an end to the tiresome journeys through this land sent to the king of the Scythians to know why he did not give him battle or acknowledge him master by sending him water and earth. Indathyrsus answered "If I fly before the prince of the Persians it is not because I fear thee, what I do now is no more than what I am used to doing in time of peace. We Scythians have neither cities or lands to defend if thou has a mind to force us to an

engagement, come and attack the tombs of our fathers and thou shalt find what manner of men we are. As to the title of master which thou assumest keep is for other nations than the Scythians. For my part I acknowledge but one master the great Jupiter one of my ancestors and the goddess Vesta." When Darius was about giving up pursuit he received from the enemy a bird, mouse, frog and five arrows, the meaning of which he was puzzled to find out as the one who delivered them refused to give any further information These for a moment caused hope to spring up in the bosom of Darius but he soon learned the meaning of these symbols which was "Know that unless you can fly like birds or hide in the earth like mice or swim in the water like frogs you shall in no wise be able to avoid the arrows of the Scythians. The Persians were after this glad to make a retreat they suffered much passing through the desolate country of the Scythians but finally arrived safely in their own country. The Scythians desiring revenge invaded some of the countries belonging to the Persians but nothing very serious was the result. Darius then formed the project of bringing India under his power in which he was successful. In the 28th year of his reign he warred with Greece. Among other cities with which he had engagements was Athens the native place of two very important of two very important characters Themistocles and Aristides the former was bold and enterprising though desirous of distinction he was much devoted to his friends exclaiming on one occasion when accused of partiality to them, "God forbid that I should ever sit upon a tribunal where my friends should find no more favor than strangers." Cleon a celebrated Athenian renounced all his friends on his becoming administrator of affairs lest they should cause him to forget his duty. Aristides who was called and seemed to have mastered the name of "The just"

observed a medium between the two. Nothing is so well calculated to show forth the virtues of men as their being contrasted with wicked men. Aristides was often placed in situations where his principles were tried but no account is given of his swerving from the path of duty. His people believed that a love of public good prompted all his actions. Miltiades was another Athenian of whom frequent mention is made in the history of the Persians and Grecians. He was a brave man and did much for his country's good but was not prompted as was Aristides for he appeared selfish at times. Such were the characters of those whom Darius had to contend with in Greece hence it is not strange that it was no easy matter to take possession of the country. The first city which he attacked was Marathon but was defeated by the Athenians though there were of them but a handful of men in comparison with the Persians. Miltiades was the able general on this occasion his army consisted of bold, intrepid men who loved liberty and dreaded slavery and tyranny more than death. Monuments were erected various parts of Greece to the memory of these men who had done so much for their country's welfare. Miltiades was not long treated kindly by the Athenians but was condemned to death being suspected of treachery. He was commuted afterwards and fined the sum of 50 talents not being able to pay was imprisoned which soon caused his death. There seemed to be much doubt of his guilt but the Athenians were desirous of disposing of him for fear his great fame and merit might enable him to gain such power over them as would cause them trouble forgetting his former services they punished him in this unjust manner. Aristides was banished from the country by the eloquence of Themistocles who then had all power in his hands. Aristides implored the gods at his departure that no accident should befall his country to cause it to regret him

Such were the troubles of the Athenians while the Persians were preparing to attack them. Darius resolving to go to war was himself this time having had his army defeated at Marathon was obliged according to law to name his successor before his departure. Though Artabarganes was his elder son Xerxes became his successor for several reasons the principal of which was that he was eldest son of the king while his brother was only the eldest son of Darius. This matter was left to Darius' brother who decided in favor of Xerxes, with which decision all seemed satisfied. Darius never returned but was much lamented by his subjects though they were aware that he was not destitute of faults. He seemed to love justice and respect laws yet many times did his passions cause him to act contrary to justice and law, Xerxes who reigned 12 years spent the first four in preparing for the war against the Grecians which his father had begun. In consequence of his care and the extent of his kingdom he commanded the largest army of which record consisting of 5,283,220. These millions of people consumed 662,040 bushels of flour per day besides other provisions in proportion which Xerxes had conveyed to them by ships. We are told that the army was so large that in order to number it they were all required to stand successively within a wall which would hold a certain number. All the Athenians in banishment were called home among whom was Aristides. All were needed at this trying time. Leonidas, a Spartan was chosen commander of the Grecian army for the first battle. His army consisted of 11,200 men determined to die if not victorious. Xerxes waited for them to flee four days after they had met when he attacked them but could not succeed in taking them till he obtained a very advantageous position. At this time Leonidas dismissed all his army save three hundred Spartans who fought

till they died all save one man who returned home to be despised by everyone. Xerxes' loss was more than 20,000. Leonidas the brave commander was caused to be hung by Xerxes who felt enraged at him for resisting him so long. Though Xerxes was apparently successful at the battle of Thermopylae yet Leonidas with the 300 Spartans who fell with him exhibited such daring and noble spirits that the Grecians were inspired with courage to fight on in defence of their country while intimidated the Persians destroying in them every hope of subverting Greece. The Athenians thought it advisable to desert Athens in order better to be able to defend other portions of their country. They had an engagement at Salamin in which place the Grecian fleets were all assembled under Themistocles who succeeded (with the aid of Aristides) in defeating the enemy and causing Xerxes to flee for safety to his own country.  Though Xerxes commanded so large an army and engaged in war so often that he was not a brave man but on the contrary was in constant fear for his own personal safety. Mardonius was left with 300,000 men to perform the work that more than 1,000,000 could not do. Mardonius tried to tempt the Athenians with beautiful presents but they informed him that nothing would tempt them to give up their liberty. Aristides gradually gained the favor of his people again and ever acted justly, he addressed one of the ambassadors of Mardonius thus "Be assured that as long as that planet (pointing to the sun) shall continue its course the Athenians will be mortal enemies to the Persians and will not cease to take vengeance of them for ravaging their lands and burning their temples." The next battle was at Plutae in which they were again successful. The Ionians left the Persians and united with the Grecians. There are many interesting accounts relative to Xerxes that might be given. I will only say that the proud and obstinate Xerxes who possessed scarcely a redeeming trait was killed by Artobanus one of his officers

Ruth
The peculiar organization of a perfect female head would be difficult to describe. That it would differ from man's in having a greater predominance of the affectionate region is inferred from the fact that in every age and nation whether barbarous or enlightened woman has been characterized for her depth and strength of affection. Her heaven on earth (should she designate any place as such)  is found at home, where she may gratify her social feelings; her friends are her all, and unless so situated as to commune with them and thus exchange those pleasing gifts, in the form of sentiments  which our Father has kindly bestowed upon his children, how dull and  insipid would life become! She feels that the bond of affection which unites kindred hearts is similar to a chain composed entirely of golden links
N6.

which naught can sever and which affliction strengthen even as rubbing causes gold to brighten. The scriptures contain many histories of individuals of both sexes but none which attracts attention so much on account of its simplicity and situation as the history of Ruth. An apt writer has compared the story of the faithful, confiding and honest Ruth, situated midway between the bloody wars of the book of Judges and "the turbulent and vindictive days of Saul and David," to the city of "Palestine with her narrow, smiling valleys, dressed with verdure and rich with plenty, but surrounded by sterile, desert sands or planted in the very jaws of rugged rocks whose naked, bold heads stand reeking in the burning sunbeams on either hand." Its peculiar situation certainly lends to increase our interest in the story as we are better able to appreciate the lovely character here represented when we compare it with those by whom it is surrounded.

short time which with gladden their hearts on the journey of life. By making these exertions as Ruth did to promote the welfare of others the good feelings in our own breasts will be strengthened, enabling us to perform our duties more cheerfully and causing our souls to become purer, and better fitted to enjoy the scenes of life. Besides a good and noble character will thus be formed, one which will follow us wherever we go and when mingling in the world to glean whatever we wish will find for us favor in the sight of all and those who have to spare will be eager to have us glean in their fields.
J.C. Stedman

heard of her conduct towards her mother with which he was much pleased and allowed her to glean there during the whole harvest and even among the sheaves.
The history of Ruth is not only interesting but instructive. We may learn from it truths which it would be well to apply in our intercourse with friends and the world. When our friends are afflicted we should not desert them but endeavor to render them assistance even when pleasant and peaceful retreats may be found far from them or gay and joyous parties are continually entreating us to join them, where we may forget that any are afflicted. When thorns spring up in the pathway of our friends we should remember to furnish them with no nourishment but assist in plucking them up; thus smoothing their pathways they will become strewn with flowers in a

Though all are no doubt familiar with the history of Ruth, it will be pleasant to have it again recalled to mind; the simplicity of the characters exhibiting at the same time great strength of affections, an implicit confidence and a sincere desire for good, is such that the mind wearies not with contemplating it but each time a review of it tends to purify at the same time that it enlightens the soul.  The widow Naomi had two sons whose wives were Ruth and Orpah, having dwelt in Moab ten years, their husbands did and they removed to Judah from whence Naomi after blessing her daughters in law bade each return to her mother's house where she might find peace and plenty.  With their kindness precious to this it appears that they had won the heart of Naomi, who, wishing them a happier home than she could offer them in her destitute

condition bade them to leave her though herself alone and afflicted.  They at first refused; finally Orpah was induced to go, for "to step aside is human," but Ruth would not leave her childless, friendless and destitute mother in law.  Having the feelings of tenderness and sympathy with which her soul was filled, wrought up she uttered a most touching and eloquent appeal to her mother in law.  She thought of leaving her mother alone and unprotected in the midst of afflictions so roused the feelings within her breast that she couched her appeal in language which as Voltaire says, has a sublimnity in its simplicity.  She said, "Entreat me not to leave thee or to return from following after thee: for where thou goest I will go; and where thou lodgest I will lodge: thy people shall be my people and thy God my God: Where thou diest will I die and there will I be buried: the Lord do so to me and more also if might but death separate thee and me,"

The constancy of Ruth!  What a strong proof of her affection for her mother and desire for her welfare!  Not in prosperity but in adversity did she cling to her.  What a noble resolve, that of following her an remaining with her to whatever hardships, fortune might expose them, knowing that a peaceful home awaited her if she would but desert Naomi; this she could not do for she felt that that home did not lie on the road of duty which she was endeavoring to follow.  They proceeded from Judah to Bethlehem, a city not far removed where they were warmly welcomed by the inhabitants.  Ruth, desirous of doing good and not too proud for any honorable employment, obtained leave to glean in the fields around Bethlehem, thinking thus to obtain provisions for herself and mother.  She went and by chance gleaned in the fields of Boaz, a wealthy relative of her deceased father in law, in whose sight she found favor for he had

June at a summer's noon.
Just released from school and feeling disposed to be sheltered from the scorching rays of a summers sun I betook myself to my favorite retreat under the branches of some trees which hung over a brook. Feeling somewhat thirsty and stupid I drank of the pure water and bathed my head after which I felt very much revived and on raising my eyes to behold the beauties spread around me exclaimed surely here is a combination of all the beauties which the taste of the most refined could desire. A little father up the stream the water descended perpendicularly from a heighth of several feet and being stuck in a certain manner by the rays of the sun presented a most beautiful appearance: colors of all the shades and hues, forms the most perfect that could be imagined being of the serpentine, all very pleasing to the eye. Then the arched expanse of the sky (with not a cloud to be seen) rendered brilliant by the glorious king of day reigning in a great splendor and magnificence. The surrounding shrubbery and trees clothed in the richest and most becoming color, in viewing which the eye never wearies, while the earth covered with a mantle of the same color but not of the same shade, upon which a herd of sheep had been grazing but had been driven away by the heat of the great luminary to take shelter under the branches of wide spreading oaks

whose tops were towering upward and which appeared, standing there in all their grandeur each to be king of all other objects, yet on casting the eye a little farther objects still more beautiful attracted my attention. A great plain covered with flowers of all kinds from the smallest and most unassuming to the largest and most brilliant, then presented itself to my view I stood and gazed with intense delight for some moments when I found that my imagination has taken its flight. How could it be otherwise under such circumstances? Impossible to keep it within bounds. Looming upward into unlimited space beholding angel forms adorned in robes of white with golden belts and rings upon their waists arms and hands floating forward and backward with all the grace peculiar to such forms and making music which adorned all who listened, but as soon as the music ceased the forms were no more to be seen. Slowly descending I came near the water which produced such beautiful colors and found that there were myriads of human beings who inhabited this to me new region. I soon found that they were what would be called in our world models of perfection being of the most beautiful shapes, sizes and arrayed in colors exactly suited to their complexions. Their faces were so beautiful and expressive, skin of the most transparent whiteness with here and there a tinge of red, hair curling over the shoulders while the eyes of a fair indication of their characters

shone  brightly and expressed volumes which I read but will not relate for want of room. By this means I found that they were as intelligent as beautiful but I could not converse with them as I did not understand their language. On leaving this pleasant region I roamed among the flowers of which I have before spoken sometimes calling some for my ladies' bouquet, then to decorate her hair, then to arrange in her parlor, sometimes reading their language and thinking how much they were like people or people like them, when I came to one whose language was Ambitious only of show. It stood much higher than the others and it was a bright but not a becoming color, for such a large flower. Everything was course about it and though it attracted attention yet it was such as the virtuous and unassuming would not desire; while the modest and more delicate were truly admired and loved not for their ostentatious show but for their real worth. 
J.C. Stedman
