There is a principle-                                                                                                                                                                       J.C. Stedman's
There is a principle implanted in a man which is denominated kindness. I need not attempt to define it as no one is supposed to be ignorant in regard to it; therefore if you wish for a definition I refer you to your own consciousness. Though all are supposed to possess feeling of kindness under favorable circumstances, yet it is a lamentable fact that the pleasure and happiness which result from its exercise is too seldom felt by the majority of mankind; even professed christians are sometimes in need of its beneficial influence. The human race placed here on the earth as one common family, having the same Father, and are constituted alike moral and accountable beings, alike liable to err and even if they occupy different stations in the world they all have to be laid in the same last narrow resting place. As it pleased out Heavenly Father this place his creatures may we not support that was also his design that they should live as bothers, seeking the interest, happiness and advancement of each other? For this reason has he implanted in man the principle of kindness, yet it is perverted in many instances by wrong education and sometimes by strong passions which are not kept

under control as they should be. In order to secure happiness which is our being's end and aim it is necessary to cultivate feelings of kindness. It will not only contribute to the happiness of your associates but to our own. It is the best instrument by which to gain the esteem and respect of others, to make warm and true friends, to make home pleasant and attractive. Kindness is first exercised in the domestic circle and is there most beautiful. A family whose constant rule of action is kindness will have a home that may be considered as a fair type of that one to which we are all journeying. Members or such families will not have to go abroad for society and thus fall into bad habits and become degraded but they bid fair to become ornaments to society. They make the most virtuous citizens for they are characterized by the same benevolent actions after having the domestic circle as they were before. As this beautiful law is less restricted it losses its strength, yet it should be cultivated; there is no danger of being too kind though. I've heard of people's being killed with kindness. It is not expected that the same feelings can be exercised towards a stranger as a relative or friend but treat him kindly and if he be unfortunately addicted to the use of ardent spirits or

any other bad habits do not repulse him but talk to him kindly, reason with him and when he finds that he is considered as somebody he will endeavor to be what he is thought to be. But pursue the opposite course and no reformation will take place.
Kindness is the chain which binds natives together and thus enables them to enjoy that peace and happiness which could result in no other way. It is more generally diffused through Christian than heathen lands owing in some measure to the ignorance of the heathens. A poet has said
Kindness is wisdom. There is none in life 
But needs it, and may learn; eye-reasoning man,
And spirit unassisted, unobscured.
Both man and womankind belie their nature 
When they are not kind. And they word are kind, And beautiful, and loving like thyself;
Thine eye and thy tongues tone and all that speak Thy soul are like it.

There is beauty --
There is beauty and sublimity in all the work of God. It is impossible to look around upon the face of nature without beholding innumerable objects of grandeur and sublimity.  From the smallest and apparently most, insignificant things of earth to the immense and lofty things of the skies do we see the comeliness of God displayed in clothing them all in the most fanciful colors and forms. He has also seen fit to bless man with an organ of vision and a sense of the sublime so that he can appreciate the beauties of nature and he may try to imitate them but can never construct anything as perfect in all its parts and therefore as pleasing to the eye as the most trifling things of nature. Flowers are better calculated to call forth admiration than things of grosser nature. Their delicate forms and beautiful tints strike the soul with inward delight which is more easily felt than described. Great admirers of beauty become so fascinated when  among them as to be transported in imagination to realms of bliss where no cares come to molest and no hardships are to be endured, where all time is spent in roaming among transplanting them from one sunny dale to another and weaving them into beautiful garlands. The majestic oak which can withstand the blasts of centuries excited in an admiration. The symmetry,  of form and hardships which it is capable of enduring

renders it an object of thought and when farther contemplated
we think of the infinite wisdom of the Creator in
forming such an immense structure from so small a thing as an acorn,
The smooth surfaces of the lake as well as the dashing
water of the cataract are objects excite in us 
feelings of admiration but more especially does the 
expansive heavens with their king to rule by day and 
sparkling stars to shine by night. Poets and giant pens have
attempted to describe its beauty and extent and have 
often failed therefore I will not attempt.
J. C. Stedman

"Tis sweet to live"
Though there come to my ears daily complaints of the world, calling it a hard one in which to live and though I hear some people presuming to wish for the power to alter and arrange circumstances to suit themselves, thinking by this means to avoid many evils, yet I can exclaim in the words of another 'Tis sweet to live. This world is rife with beauty and happiness. It is only necessary to understand how to enjoy it in order to be convinced that it is truly a luxury to live. He who would reach the highest degree of happiness attainable in this world must philosophize, must understand the right method of procuring the object which he has in view, so application is indispensably requisite to the prospering in any of the arts or sciences so is it necessary to study in order to be able to enjoy life, to appreciate the many blessings which are daily showered upon us. In order to be able to enjoy anything, we must understand what it is and the various means by which to derive pleasure from it. It is well known that a novice in music could listen to the sweetest strains without experiencing the least pleasant emotion, while an accomplished musician would consider it a rich treat, be so perfectly delighted as to forget every thing else for the time being and like enough fancy himself in fairyland. The cause of the difference in the feelings of these individuals must be attributable to the difference in their capacities to appreciate. Therefore I say that he who would enjoy life must develop those powers which have been implanted in him in such a manner that he may be susceptible of experiencing pleasant emotions whenever an opportunity is offered, It is obvious that by cultivating our reasoning faculties a great amount of pleasure will result to us which could be obtained in no other way and when once we experience that pleasure we would not part with the power by which 
N12

it was obtained for any price. Nay, it is of inestimable value, that only will the development of our reasoning faculties afford us pleasure but also our moral and affectionate natures if rightly brought out will be the means of affording us as much if not more enjoyment. In order to constitute an individual susceptible of the highest enjoyment he must have all his faculties equally and fully developed (a limit to which man has never reached) yet those who are deficient in many things requisite to the highest degree of happiness may be happy, that is enjoy all that they are capable of enjoying, but the higher the life the more perfect the powers of judgment, of imagination and of intensity of feeling the greater will be the capacity of enjoying. To him who has all his faculties properly cultivated there is much to live for of which an uneducated person is incapable of conceiving. It is impossible for him to draw a breath without experiencing much pleasure; that act though simple in itself might lead the mind into a train of thought which would be highly fraught with beauty and happiness. If the mind were not otherwise occupied it would naturally cause thoughts of the Deity to fill the mind from which would follow feelings of gratitude towards him who dispenses to us the blessing of breathing without which we would be as nothing. The peculiar manner in which man is formed to answer the design for which it appears he was created is a subject of great interest and thoughts regarding it would naturally occupy the mind subsequent to those mentioned, the contemplation of which would afford great pleasure, embracing as it does the sciences of physiology, physiognomy and phrenology, and if not interrupted the mind which started with the thoughts called forth by the simple act of breathing would pass over all those beautiful and highly entertaining thoughts which are the result of a thorough acquaintance with these sciences. The beauty of all the laws relating to these sciences are their peculiar adaptation to the wants of man strike the

mind as indeed worthy of investigation and while contemplating them how all powerful does that sublime and ever desirable to b e remembered truth come home to as that Infinite Wisdom must have created all these. The mind after dwelling upon such thoughts for a time would find many roads upon which to travel, till it would take in every department of science, but it would be too difficult a task for my feeble pen to trace out all its windings; therefore I will leave it for the hearer to follow it for himself and he will no doubt find that there are many, very many reasons why we should consider life a blessing in consequence of the many sources from which we may derive pleasure. If so comparatively trifling an act as a mere breath may cause so much pleasure may we not even without calling upon the imagination  suppose that if every privilege which we enjoy for pleasure were fully appreciated that this world would be full of happiness instead of misery and wretchedness? It remains with ourselves then whether we are happy or miserable, consequently when we hear people complaining we may consider the as acknowledging that they are ignorant on that subject which of all others it is desirable to be acquainted with viz. the proper method of enjoying life, of turning every thing to the best advantage of appreciating those things designed for our happiness. On the other hand be who is cheerful and happy under all circumstances may be considered as one who has been instructed in all those things exquisite for this comfort and well being. He feels sensible of the fact that it "'Tis sweet to live." Ah! yes, far from every circumstance however trivial be reaps a golden harvest of pleasure. If the sun shines be thankful  for he can spend that time in working and thus invigorates his system and provide for coming wants, but if clouds darken the bright and beautiful sky he is not only satisfied with the change.

but the scene strikes his mind is indeed glorious and when the thunder rolls the lightening darts through the sky, the winds blow and rain falls how intensely ground and sublime as the sight to him. How beautiful are the thoughts which fill his mind, as he beholds the scene, contemplating the great amount of good that will result from these canvases and admiring the skill of Him who arranged and brought them into existence. Rain or shine is alike agreeable to him as he does not depend alone upon outward circumstance for comfort peace and happiness, but upon the great store house of knowledge the contents of which "moth will not corrupt or thieves break through and steal." It is the only sure source of happiness as it is not naturally changed by outward circumstances, By cultivating all these faculties implanted in us in harmony we will thus secure for ourselves a never failing source of pleasure. If all would do this it is impossible to conceive the whole result but it is evident that the flag of peace would wave over early land and the airy resound throughout The Universe "'Tis sweet to
Josephine

Truly -
Truly has it been said that "man's happiness does not consist in his outward circumstances; and that all the advantages of what I've called good fortune may bring nothing but wretchedness instead of adding for a single moment to his happiness."
The germ of happiness lies within, and nothing external can of itself contribute to our enjoyment. Wealth honors and sincere in various pursuits may appear to be the principle source of enjoyment, but all of these without the heart is right and peace resigns within will not produce happiness. It is absurd to suppose that it can exist either in houses, lands or any of the good thing of this world but that they earn and do contribute to man's happiness when he is what he should be I will not sing. If we be happy our happiness must be in our hearts, must spring from within.
If we have a mind to see wealth as it should be, if we are always sure to use moderately what we have it does then contribute to our happiness but how often do we see those with more than a competency sunk in misery and awareness. The passions become stronger as they are gratified and it is out of the power of fortune to render those happy who are corrupt and full of ungodly passions.
Our every day experience furnishes us with instances which go to prove the truth of what has been said namely that when envy hatred malice or any of the evil passions exist within it an impossible for that person to be happy through surrounded by all that wealth can listen and also that pure happiness can be found where fortune has not smiled if the mind is nicely adorned with virtuous and contended feelings.

It is no uncommon thing to see those whom fortune has smiled upon, living amid all that wealth can bestow, deprived of no luxuries, at liberty to spend their time as they will with servants to do their bidding wretched, with nothing peaceful or happy about them, time hanging heavily over them, and we often hear them complaining of their lot, considering it a hard one to be borne, and who ought to complain if not those with heavy hearts and uncontented dispositions for they are so very burdensome.  But on the other hand we may enter the abode of the poor, of those who would be called the unfortunate people and find contentment, where the want of luxuries is not felt and the desire for ease is not known and the fact that here is home with all its happy influences is sufficient to render the room however small and wanting in adornments a place of interest and enjoyment.
J. C. Stedman

"Virtue is the only Amaranthine flower on Earth" and Society is the proper soil in which to nourish it. 
What is more gentle or purer in the sight of God or man than virtue? As there is nothing it may truly be called an Amaranthine flower and that it is the only one is evident from the fact that it embraces every quality that is really good and gentle. Virtue like the sun shines not by borrowed light but actually contains the substance, which makes it appear so bright, lovely, and attractive, and like the sun sends its rays upon other bodies to gladden them with its gentle radiance. Notwithstanding it is so very beautiful and attractive and is so universally admired by all in every land yet it is often banished from the presence of individuals of high standing.They can but admire it in others but strive not to obtain it for themselves.
Everyone has within him the seeds of every virtue and it depends upon the soil in which he places them, the nourishment which he gives them and the care which he bestows upon them whether they grow to perfection or become stinted at an early day. As every one has been provided with the seeds of every virtue is it not a duty devolving upon him to nourish those seeds in the best manner possible, to provide suitable soil for their growth and to watch over them with the most vigilant care lest they be uprooted or demolished?
If they be neglected, the most unhappy results will be the consequence but with proper cultivation they will soon sprout and continue to grow in beauty and strength and will shine forth as brilliant diadems through life. The most effectual method of bringing them to perfection is seldom well understood. To the inexperienced the course which it is necessary to take in order to bring the flower to perfection appears difficult, it appears to have too many windings but this is owing to a want of attention, to negligence or a desire to try some other way. By steadily pursuing the right course it is found to be direct, full of beauty and pleasure. Life passes

sweetly with those who follow its course and when it is over they can depart in peace feeling that they have not lived in vain. But where are those seeds to be nourished and the flowers reared? In solitude? Do we see the choicest flowers growing alone, isolated from all of their kind? No, they are to be found in groups either in garden on hillside or wherever it has pleased the Creator to place them. A flower never thrives when alone it seems to be in need of something, which it has not, it wants something to live for of the same kind with itself, it is the same with the Amaranthine flower, Virtuous is is impossible for it to become as beautiful when reared in solitude as in society for there selfish was would be constantly hindering it in its onward progress while society seems exactly adapted to its nourishment and perfection.The love and regard felt for those around whether they be relatives, friends or acquaintances inspires feelings of purity and holiness. The depth of the soul is fathomed and whatever of good is found there is brought forth and by constant use becomes strengthened and thus by mingling in society all that is good and virtuous belonging to our natures is encouraged till it becomes after awhile an easy thing to adhere strictly to virtue. It is in society that we meet our friends and cultivate an attachment for them and the stronger these feelings of attachment are the greater is the desire to be worthy of their love and esteem. Where such feelings reign in the heart there is no danger of haughty pride intruding for love, hope and all that is gentle occupies the ground and pride does not like their company. It is the same with every vice, they wish not the company of the virtues, hence they enter not those places where the virtues reign. Such beings are constituted for friends and always have many, the society in which they mingle is made up of friends , and how delightful it is to be surrounded by them to know that there are those around who can sympathize with us if sorrows depress or can rejoice with us if bright prospects elate us. When doing a praiseworthy act we can feel that we will not be flattered for it but that whatever comes to our ears of commendation is sent to encourage us in the good cause in which we are engaged and it rebuked for doing wrong (as a true friend will never fail to do so) how welcome is it received. Society is the true sphere in which to cherish the virtues as there the strongest and most lasting friendships are found, consequently, there is the place where all that is noble and good is displayed and all that is wicked and unbecoming is refrained from, where all passions and emotions that are not characteristic of a lady or gentleman are subdued. True the members of all societies are not equally characterized morality and virtue but that it has a tendency to foster them must be evident and that all are not thus affected who mingle in it or have been thrown into bad society and from want of discernment pursued the wrong till now it is difficult for the, to break off their bad habits. The beneficial effects produced by society are great. It enables many to undergo severe trials and resist strong Temptations in order to be worthy members of the society to which they belong.

A Visit to Blannerhasset's Island 
Some young people were desirous of having a hay day celebration, accordingly they made preparations to go upon Blannerhasset's Island. Having assembled at the proper time and place they all crossed the river together; some to visit that celebrated Island for the first time and to actually see the ground on which once stood the palace of Blannerhasset. Thus remains nothing to speak of its former beauty as it was destroyed by fire many years ago and no one of the family was left in these parts to keep the yard in order, so it grew up to weeds trees etc. But there is a well the remains of a gatepost and a cellar to be seen which we examined carefully and then made our way to some trees under whose shade we rested and chose our Queen, one whom every one thought beautiful and accomplished enough to receive the crown which was a wreath of wild flowers that we gathered upon the Island. The Queen was but seventeen years old and yet she seemed to be matured in mind and body. She won all hearts to her by her gentle manner and pleasant conversation and when rambling around upon the Island every flower that was found was presented to her and she would give its language and analyze it besides making other remarks which were very interesting to everyone. We called at a house that stands on the Island not far from the place which we had selected for our resting place to get some water and were invited to enter. We did so and found the inmates of that house consistent if but one old man

and his daughter. I was much surprised to learn this and much more so to find that they were happy for I could not see what happiness could be taken away from friends but I found that they were everything to each other that they had a large library which took up much of their time, the daughter reading to the father and he explaining what she did not understand. But apparently the greatest source of pleasure to them was music in which they were both proficient. The daughter played on the harp and sung while the father accompanied with the violin for our entertainment; we enjoyed it very much but as it was getting late we were under the necessity of leaving though urged to remain. We prevailed on the daughter to accompany us to out retreat where we had some refreshments of which everyone partook with alacrity as our appetite had become quite good after our long ramble. While partaking of these refreshments this daughter said she was very well contented with her situation, that she had no desire to live in any more public place for she knew that she should not be able to appreciate her friends as she now did for she would have an opportunity to see them often and she feared she would not have so much time to devote to intellectual pursuits. On out return home we had something to think about. I think I learned something from this visit and that is that to be happy any one must be contented
J.C. Stedman

Want of Piety arises from a want of sensibility 
There is nothing clearer to my mind than that the want of veneration or love for the Author of all things arises from a want of perception or susceptibility of impression. Around us on every side are objects of great beauty and magnificence which from their harmony and beautiful arrangements together with their adaption to the wants of man clearly prove that they must have been formed by a being of unbounded benevolence as well as of great wisdom and power. There is a provision made for all of mans wants. Something with which to gratify all his appetites, desires an affections. He has not been endowed with an appetite for food and drink with nothing to satisfy hunger or quench thirst but it has been wisely ordered that there should be sufficient food and drink for all living creatures and a means provided for their replenishment. By an unseen power water is transferred from the earth upward where it remains in the form of clouds till it is again needed on the earth when it descends to refresh and invigorate it for many useful purposes, We are surrounded by friends who feel interested for us and which whom we have much pleasure conversing upon different topics, thus interchanged thoughts and feelings, which is a source of great happiness to us. Besides such pleasure there are many others such as beautiful objects to please the eye and give inward delight to the soul, harmonious sounds to charm the ear

but I think I have enumerated enough for my present purpose. From whom do we receive all these blessings? A Being whom we do not love and adore? I fear too many can answer yes. Yet it must be owing to a want of perception when so much unmistakable evidence is before us. It is the nature of man to worship some Being for the heathen who know nothing of revelation worship dumb animals or some inanimate object, but man has perverted his nature and  it is for this he is to blame. The more intellectual portion of the community are not in fault but in comparing the religious with the irreligious we compare the respectable and more intelligent with the degraded and ignorant and that the cause of this difference is their religion is evident. A celebrated writer says "On every page of the Christian revelation it is clearly written, or implied, that our religion is final; that it furnishes the true law of individual growth and the only code of social progress and perfection Its promise is to furnish for the world a system of universal education". If it promise a universal education surely it must be plain and easily comprehended. Therefore I conclude that those who in this age of light and knowledge are not able to see the dependence of man on a Supreme Being and feel that to Him is due all honor, love, and praise must necessarily be deficient in the perceptive region or destitute of feeling any impressions however forcible.

Whether ye eat or drink or whatever ye do, do all to the glory of God. Man is placed on earth with everything necessary for his sustenance and happiness at his command. It has been so ordained that he is capable of bringing every living thing in subjection to his power, though not possessed of half the strength of many of them. Behold the fierce tiger an how subdued and rendered as obedient as a little child by a being far weaker than itself. It is knowledge and not strength that renders man capable of accomplishing such things. As he has been endowed with the proper requisites for prosecuting such difficult and far nobler acts may we not infer that it was for some wise purpose? Then I ask is it consistent with these views for man to show forth selfish dispositions and harbor unkind thoughts against those individuals who seem to prosper in whatever undertaking they engage? Yet there is much selfishness in the world. In every nation this propensity may be seen existing though contrary to the injunctions "Whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God and love thy neighbor as thyself". The conscience is the peoples guide on all occasions where right and wrong are considered; for it fells us whether we are actuated by selfish motives or the more benevolent spirit of the good of out fellowmen or the love of God. It is necessary to have the love of God abroad in the heart in order to act at all times with a view to his glory, but it is contrary to the scriptures to suppose that anyone is perfect therefore I conclude that

the more love for God (which is shown by a respect for religious things) anyone has, the nearer to perfection has he arrived and the more willing is he to say "Thy will be done."  It is hard sometimes to submit to afflictions which are ours to bear and for a moment we may feel that they are not for the best but after due consideration such thoughts will vanish and the afflictions will be borne not only with resignation but the heart will be softened and the afflicted one will feel like glorifying God for his dispensations.  In contemplating the mind, the greatest gift of God to man it is impossible to present feelings of adoration towards the Giver from springing into being within us.  The bounties spread for the morning and evening meal should not be partaken merely for our own good but our thoughts should revert to the Creator from whose hands they proceed and a feeling of reverence will consequently occupy our minds which will be very pleasant for it is impossible to contemplate a Being of unlimited power and the Giver of all good and perfect gifts who attends to all his creature's numerous wants with any other feelings.
J. C. Stedman

Notwithstanding it is so very beautiful and attractive and is so universally admired in every land by the great and good yet it is often times banished from the presence of individuals of high standing. Everyone has within him the seeds of every virtue and it is owning to the soil in which he places them whether they grow to perfection or become stinted at an early day. NIDa

in groups and so is it necessary for the growth and perfection of the Amaranthine flower, Virtue. It is impossible for it to become as beautiful when reared in solitude for selfishness, that bone of human joy would be constantly hindering it in its onward progress. But society seems to be exactly adapted to the nourishment and perfection of Virtue; selfishness cannot there be indulged. The love and regard felt for those around whether they be relatives, friends  or acquaintances inspires feelings of purity and holiness, and the stronger these feelings of astonishment become the greater in the desire felt to be worthy of the love and esteem of those by whom we are surrounded. In society friendships are formed true and lasting. The purest and holiest findings of the soul are called out. Haughty pride lies not reign in of such hearts but hope, love and all that is gentle are found there in abundance. When sorrows depress there are kindred hearts to sympathize with you and when bright prophets elate there are friends who will be joyful with you and when you act in a praiseworthy manner deserved commendation will meet your ears and not unmeaning flattery but if wrong is done there are among the true friends those who will chide and how welcome is the rebuke received. All the virtues may be easily cherished in society. By showing an interest in others by writing yourself with them and acknowledging yourself as belonging to the land at once going for you a feeling of kindness a brotherly love and you will intuitively undergo many trials resist strong temptations in order to be worthy of the love lavished upon you.

Wisdom
So the question what is Wisdom? various answers would be given by different individuals. It is used in the Scriptures in a very difficult sense from the one in which it is generally used by mankind. In the Scriptures Wisdom is always spoken of as a means by which good and happy results are effected, but we often hear those called wise who possess knowledge whether it be used for a good purpose or not. A very clear and comprehensive answer may be found in the following. Wisdom is light and reason. Anything composed of such valuable ingredients must naturally be very pure, lovely and attractive. For truth is the most precious of all things; it will make us free from that state of mind which is a debasing in its nature, and light is very essential in rendering the truths presented for consideration easily understood. Reason decides which is the best and surest course to take in order to secure the desired end which Wisdom always has in vision, good to all. Its ability is beautifully expressed in the following comparison. "Wisdom resembles an open foundation whose waters are never sealed up but are kept constantly running for the benefit of all."
N2

The association of Wisdom with a fountain brings to our minds clear ideas of its purity, beauty and usefulness. There certainly is a very striking resemblance as we shall see by revisiting the fountain where in childhood we were wont to go after our lessons were recited to bathe our cherubic faces and little hands and to watch the crystal waters as they gurgled forth from it and ran along through the meadow and down the valley making at every moment some new turn. We would watch them till they were lost in the distance and then wish to follow them to their destination. As we are grown now and there is no danger of being sent for if we run off let us follow the stream to the end. Alas! I fear it will lead us a long chase, - here we go through meadow and field till it is joined by another stream. It has turned out of its former course and is going in an entirely different direction but for what reason? Unless it is to do the most good? Oh! yes, it is for that it will thus furnish this old washerwoman with water at her hand and the horses, cows and sheep in this large field may have some of it to quench their thirst. On a little further it is joined by another and another stream each tending to make it larger more powerful and more useful till now it may be called a creek. As we were to follow it to its destination

to anything that man has or can invent.  Its bounty is never concealed from the eye of the observer, the countenance betrays it.  It announces the thoughts and sentiments within as correctly as thought expressed in language.  As the mind is more enlightened every feature changes, but it never reaches perfection here, there is always something yet to learn.  When it has reached a great eminence it resembles the ocean whose waters could be traced no further for it is always at an advanced age that this is attained and then death comes after which it may go on to perfection.
"Hail source of infinite delight!
Hail beams of truth inspiring light!
Hail dawning of immortal birth!
Hail solace of the soul on earth!"

and as it rolls majestically through the rocky glen and barren waste it gives fertility to all around causing the "desert to bloom as the rose" and though it parts with some of its properties yet it becomes mightier in the language of another "its light is none the less for lighting its neighbors."  Nature whispers to it of the triumphs of knowledge and its glorious achievements.  As time hastens on it continues to increase enriching and purifying the soul of man as does the water fertilize the earth and aid him in procuring the necessaries of life.  When is has reached this point, its grandeur is almost indescribable and soon another and another mighty current comes rushing in to swell it as the new streams increased the original waters.  How profound has its placid current become since it started for now its sphere is not limited to a few individuals but it flows on without restraint benefitting all mankind.  The mind also resembles the waters in being beautiful for what is more worthy of admiration than a well stored mind adorned with all necessary attractions.  It is as much more lovely than anything mortal as are those shining orbs that roll in silent majesty through the arched canopy of heaven

let us not tire but pursue it still farther; at every short distance it is increased by new streams flowing into it, but we have come to a mill which is turned by the water of this stream thus affording means to the miller by which to convert the grain raised by the farmer into flour and meal for food.On, on we go the stream continually increasing, new waters joining the main waters till it has become a river but it does not end here, therefore we must not tire. We see at every little distance boars and towns clinging very closely to the water, yes, for it is from this they gain their sustenance. Still more rivers join it till it has become so wide we can hardly see across it therefore we can pursue it but little farther. We shall soon get to the ocean; we are there and it is useless to try to proceed for the water sometimes runs in one direction and sometimes in another. Since we can go no further let us consider what is the use of all this. The stream has been of great use from the first for the larger and more powerful it became the greater good it accomplished. No charges were made or thank yous said for its water and yet everyone who desired could use as much as they wanted and for any use they wanted it, but I am sure they are welcome to it for there is plenty and to spare. I hope it has accomplished great good caused many hearts to bound with joy and gladness and I am
N2                              2

confident it has for the old man who came to the spring for a sparkling draught said it always made him happy it made him think of the Allwise Giver from whose hands we receive it besides its purity reminded him of his childhood days when he was innocent before any clouds had darkened his horizon. He loved to dwell on the time. All the children seemed brighter and happier after sipping of the pure water and how thankful that old miller looked, if he did not say so his actions plainly told, for he knows it is the means by which he can procure food for his wife and darling children. The old washer woman is furnished with means by which to live; it contributed to the enjoyment of all who made use of it and the larger it grew the more useful it became. But it may now be asked how does Wisdom resemble it? we can neither take it up in a glass and drink it nor will it turn a mill, but yet there is another way. The mind the seat of Wisdom in infancy resembles the place from which the waters originated; it is at first limited in its power to do good only serving to render happy those who come directly under its influence. But it soon receives additions from without which extend its circle of usefulness; more truths are presented which it grasps with eagerness

all of which tend to strengthen it and then it flows gently
and silently onward still continuing to become more beneficial
as it is expanded by truths which bear the same resemblance
to it that the new streams did to the large waters. How joyful
does it make those around to see the eye of the youth sparkling
with intellectual fire as some new thought steals into the 
mind and is treasured up as as choice gem for they know
it will be like good seed placed in fertile soil which
in time will bring forth abundance of fruits. As the 
mind progresses in its onward course it becomes stronger and
more useful, if not only sheds its influence upon those of a kindred
nature but its scope becomes more extended and mankind in
general are thereby benefitted. But it stops not here, all the 
wondrous mysteries of science are gradually upon its
mental vision, each fact tending not only to fit it for
future usefulness but to develop it for its own happiness. 
Whether lone, weary and responding in Africas wilderness
or Indias sands or Polar snows man is cheered by the 
light which wisdom sheds into his darkened abode.
Speak not of its monotony for it leaps on with joyous,
exhaustless within the seeds of virtue and knowledge
